newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: CIL to sell Aust property for NZ$52 mln.
newsitem.headline: CIL to sell Aust property for NZ$52 mln.

text.p: Corporate Investments Ltd said on Friday it had entered into a contract for the sale of Fifty Cavill Avenue Pty, the company that owns the office tower at 50 Cavill Avenue, Surfers Paradise, Australia.
"After taking account of all costs, inclusive of a rental guarantee until June 30, 1998, the sale provides a net return of NZ$52 million (A$46 million)," CIL said in a statement.
The return was equal to CIL's book value for the building.
The sale contract was conditional only upon the Australia Foreign Investment Review Board's (AFIRB) approval. Should that be forthcoming, settlement was expected before June 30.
The building is currently 95 percent leased, and is being sold to an international investor.
CIL chief executive Bryan Mogridge told Reuters it was up to that party to disclose its identity.
"I suspect they'll do that over there (Australia) in their own due time," he said.
Mogridge said he was confident the sale would go through.
"This is only conditional upon one thing. Subject to the AFIRB, I am 100 percent confident," he said.
CIL said all funds from the sale would be used to repay debt.
The completion of the sale will bring to a close the major reconstruction of the CIL Group which began five years ago.
The company will now largely comprise Montana Wines (80 percent of gross assets) and Truck Investments (12 percent of gross assets).
CIL said the profit growth of the company would come from the expansion of the Montana Wines business, both at home and overseas.
